tit.e: The Shijo School of the Way of the Kitchen Knife

sen.j: 四条流庖丁道（しじょうりゅうほうちょうどう）は、平安時代から始まると伝えられる日本料理の流派。
sen.e: The Way of Kitchen-Knife in Shijo School is a school of Japanese cuisine which is said to have originated in the Heian period.
The Shijo School of the Way of the Kitchen Knife ("Shijoryu-Hochodo" in Japanese) is a school of Japanese cuisine which is said to have originated in the Heian period.

sen.j: 庖丁道（庖丁式）とは料理に関する作法・故実や調理法などを最も頻用する調理器具の包丁で象徴した呼び名である。
sen.e: The way of kitchen-knife (or the kitchen-knife method) is a name given for manners, documents and records of the past and art of cooking, with a symbol of a kitchen-knife which is one of the most frequently-used cooking utensils.

The way of the kitchen knife (or the kitchen knife method) is the name given to cooking-related matters such as the art of cooking, its etiquette, and its traditions, and it has as its symbol one of the most frequently used cooking utensils, the kitchen-knife.
sen.cmt: I realize the Japanese doesn't say "matters" as such but a clearer link between the name and what it means needed to be made. Also, "manners, documents and records of the past and art of cooking" could be made more concise, I think.

sen.j: 四条流の起源は、藤原山蔭（四条中納言、824年 - 888年）が、光孝天皇の勅命により庖丁式（料理作法）の新式を定めたことに由来すると伝えられている。
sen.e: it is said that the the Shijo School was derived from a new kitchen-knife method (cooking manner) which was establisehd by FUJIWARA no Yamakage (Shijo Chunagon (Shijo Middle Councillor) 824-888) in obedience to an Emperor Koko's ordinance.

It is said that the the Shijo School was derived from a new kitchen-knife method (cooking manner) which was establisehd by FUJIWARA no Yamakage (Shijo Chunagon, or Shijo Vice-Councilor, 824-888) in accordance with an order given by the Emperor Koko.

sen.j: 朝廷の料理は宮内省に属す内膳司が司っていたが、山蔭は内膳職とは関係がなく、単に料理法や作法に通じた識者として指名されたものか。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Yamakage is supposed to have been simply designated as an expert well-versed in cookery and manners, because he was nothing to do with the Emperor's dietary office of the Imperial Household Bureau which was in charge of the food served at Court.

sen.j: 9世紀の段階で、唐から伝えられた食習慣・調理法が日本風に消化されて定着しつつあったと思われ、それらをまとめて有職故実という形で山蔭が結実させたものであろう。
sen.e: Since the food custom and recipes introduced from Tang (China) is supposed to have been assimilated and taking root in Japan in the ninth century, the custom and recipes may have been integrated into Yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, documents and records of the past) by Yamakage.

sen.j: 山蔭の確立した庖丁式は、藤原北家魚名流の藤原隆季を祖とする四条家に家業として伝えられ「四条流」と呼ばれることになる。
sen.e: The kitchen-knife method established by Yamakage was handed down as the family profession to the Shijo family which is affililated with the House of Fujiwara North, Uona Line and descended from FUJIWARA no Takasue; therefore, the method was to be called "Shijo school".

The kitchen-knife method established by Yamakage was handed down as a family profession to the Shijo family which was affililated with the Northern House of Fujiwara, Uona Line and descended from FUJIWARA no Takasue; therefore, the method was called "Shijo school".

The kitchen-knife method established by Yamakage was handed down as a family profession to the Shijo family which was affililated with the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, Uona Line and descended from FUJIWARA no Takasue; therefore, the method was called 'Shijo School.'
sen.cmt: 「藤原北家」→the Northern House of the Fujiwara clanに修正、'Shijo School'としピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: なお、山蔭も魚名流（藤原鷲取系）であるが、四条家（藤原末茂系）とは別流であり、系譜的には直系ではない（詳細は藤原北家の各流系図を参照）。
sen.e: Since Yamakage is also affililated with the Uona Line (FUJIWARA no Washitori branch) but belongs to a school different from that of the Shijo family (FUJIWARA no Sueshige branch), Yamakage is not a direct ancestor of the Shijo family in the family tree (for further details, also refer to a family tree of each line of the House of Fujiwara North.).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代中期に中御門家持明院基家の三男で園家を興した園基氏が、四条流を学んで別派を興し「四条園流（もしくは単に園流）」と称された（なお基氏は華道にも通じ、青山流を創始している）。
sen.e: In the middle of the Kamakura period, Motouji SONO who was a third son of Motoie JIMYOIN of the Nakano-Mikado family and who started the Sono family learned the way of kitchen-knife in Shijo School and established another school than Shijo School which was to be called "Shijo-Sono school" (or simply Sono school) (Motouji was also well-versed in flower arrangement and originated Aoyama school.).

sen.cmt: the Nakano-Mikado→the Nakanomikadoとし、シングルクォーテーションに変更、余分なピリオド削除

sen.j: 室町時代には足利氏征夷大将軍家に仕えた四条流の庖丁人（料理人）・大草公次（三郎左衛門）が「大草流」起こす、畠山氏（詳細不明）から畠山流も起こる、その畠山流の由来、その仕立て方、庖丁式、食事作法など膳部一切を旗本進士次郎左衛門尉へ伝え進士流が起こる、公家社会のみならず武家社会における料理においても、四条流の分派が浸透しはじめた。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, - Kimitsugu (Saburozaemon) OKUSA (a master of kitchen-knife (cooker) of Shijo School) who had served the Shogun family of Ashikaga clan established "Okusa school", - also, Hatakeyama school started from the Hatakeyama family (detailes unknown), - the origin of Hatakeyama school and everything from its preparation to manners including the recipe, the kitchen-knife method, and the table manners were transferred to Jirozaemonnojo SHINJI (shogun's retainer) who was to establish Shinji school, and - branches of Shijo School started to take hold in the cuisine not only in the Court noble society but also in the Bushi society.

sen.j: また四条流を学んだ園部和泉守という庖丁人が三河国松平氏に仕えていたが、松平元康（徳川家康）が天下人となり江戸幕府を創始すると、「四条園部流」が幕府の台所を預かることとなり、江戸時代には各藩へも普及が進んだ。
sen.e: When Motoyasu MATSUDAIRA (Ieyasu TOKUGAWA) became a ruler of Japan and established the Edo bakufu, "Shijo-Sonobe school" was decided to be in charge of the cuisine of the bakufu, since Sonobe Izuminokami (a master of kitchen-knife who had learned in Shijo School) had served the Matsudaira family of Mikawa Province; consequently, that promoted to prevail Shijo School among domains in the Edo period.

sen.j: 四条流庖丁式の次第が記述され、まな板の名所・寸法などから記載が始まり、続いて具体的な料理法や、箸・膳の飾り方なども記載されており、当時の日本料理の素材や調理法を知る上で貴重な史料となっている。
sen.e: Since the book contains a description of the ritual of the kitchen-knife method in Shijo School as well as descriptions starting with the naming and size of each place of cutting board, followed by specific recipes, and decoration methods of chopsticks and eating utensils, it is now considered as a valuable historical source of information on materials and art of cooking of the Japanese cuisine of those days.
